awd_titl_txt: CCF: AF: Small: Simulating Hamiltonian dynamics: Algorithms and applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Simulating the dynamics of quantum systems is a major potential application of quantum computers.  Quantum simulation can be applied, for example, to model chemical reactions and to predict the behavior of materials.  It can also be used as a tool to develop other quantum algorithms, and its study sheds light on the power of quantum computers.  This project focuses on two related aspects of quantum simulation: developing improved quantum algorithms for basic simulation problems and studying applications of quantum simulation to other computational tasks.

While the state of the art in quantum simulation algorithms is fairly advanced, the ultimate limits for this fundamental task remain unclear.  Operating within a broadly applicable framework of quantum systems described by sparse matrices, the project aims to develop optimal tradeoffs among all relevant simulation parameters.  It also studies quantum algorithms for simulating open quantum systems, leveraging algorithmic ideas from the well-studied scenario of noiseless systems to give new algorithms for the more realistic setting of noisy quantum systems that interact with their environments.  Furthermore, the project studies applications of quantum simulation algorithms.  Quantum simulation is the core component of a quantum algorithm for extracting information about the solutions of large systems of linear equations.  The project applies recent improvements to quantum simulation algorithms to give improved quantum algorithms for linear systems.  It also studies the computational power of particular types of linear systems, such as those that arise in the computation of effective resistances in electrical networks.  Finally, the project investigates how algorithmic ideas from advanced quantum simulation algorithms can be applied outside the context of simulation, e.g., in computational number theory.

por.por_cntn:
One of the most significant potential applications of quantum computers is the task of simulating the dynamics of quantum systems. Quantum simulation can be directly applied to problems such as modeling chemical reactions and predicting the behavior of materials. It can also be used as a tool to develop other quantum algorithms. This project focused on two related aspects of quantum simulation: developing improved quantum algorithms for basic simulation problems and studying applications of quantum simulation to other computational tasks.

Quantum simulation algorithms typically rely on an analysis showing that the simulation error is small to ensure that the output of the simulation is reliable. One contribution of the project was to develop improved methods for bounding errors in quantum simulation algorithms, resulting in more efficient simulations. The project also developed some of the first algorithms for simulating so-called open quantum systems, allowing quantum simulators to perform intentionally noisy operations in a controlled way.

The project also explored applying quantum simulation algorithms to study problems in physics, such as the behavior of chemical systems or novel materials. To work toward a practical near-term application of quantum computers, we identified a classically-hard instance of quantum simulation that is among the easiest to address with early quantum devices. We developed optimized implementations and performed detailed resource analyses for several leading quantum algorithms for this problem. By evaluating the best approaches to small-scale quantum simulation, we provided a detailed blueprint for what could be the first practical application of quantum computers. Motivated by this work, we also identified a new connection between quantum simulation and the locality of quantum interactions, showing that ideas from quantum simulation can be used to bound how quickly information can propagate in a quantum system.
Finally, the project explored applications of quantum simulation to other algorithmic tasks. In particular, recent work has shown that quantum simulation can be used as a tool to perform linear algebra in Hilbert space, producing quantum representations of high-dimensional vectors much more rapidly than one could produce a complete classical description. Perhaps the most natural example is the case of systems of linear equations, a fundamental problem that occurs throughout science and engineering. We gave a quantum algorithm for producing a state proportional to the solution of a large, sparse system of linear equations with complexity polynomial in both the number of variables and the logarithm of the inverse error. This dependence on the simulation error represents an exponential improvement over previous work, and the techniques developed to achieve this will likely be useful for other quantum algorithms. We also developed an algorithm with similar performance for producing a quantum state proportional to the solution of a system of ordinary differential equations, another central problem in science and engineering.

The algorithms and algorithmic tools discovered in the course of this project shed new light on the power of quantum computers. They could also be used for a variety of potentially revolutionary applications, including simulations for chemical and materials design, finite element analysis, scientific computing, and machine learning. The project also provided training and research experiences for several graduate students, an undergraduate student, and a postdoctoral scholar.
